results.title: Duck soup
results.brief_description: The funniest Marx Brothers film is thankfully free of tacked-on studio romance, free of sentimentality and it is joyously anarchic. Groucho is head of the struggling country of Freedonia. Battling power-hungry courtiers and devious politicians, the four brothers have to defend their tiny country from the threat of war. “Duck Soup” includes some of the funniest dialogue and innovative visual comedy in the history of film including the classic “fake-mirror” scene, the lemonade-stand torture scene and the Civil War spoof. This film has inspired directors as diverse as Woody Allen and Stanley Kubrick. “Duck Soup” is hilarious, witty, and vulgar. War has never been so ridiculous, patriotism has never been so wondefully subverted.

results.title: Drunken angel
results.creator_credit: Toho Kabushiki Kaisha and Akira Kurosawa
results.brief_description: In 1948 the American army of occupation was still in situ in Japan; Toho, one of Japan’s biggest film production houses and producers of the films of Akira Kurosawa, was riven by strikes - the US Army actually dispersed striking union members who had occupied the Toho site. Against such a backdrop, that any film came out of the Toho state is remarkable. That Kurosawa was able to create a contemporary thriller which was allegorical to the condition of the country, a film rich in traditional Japanese imagery and values, highly esteemed by the critics of his own country - is nothing short of miraculous. Toshiro Mifune takes his first lead role in a Kurosawa film (he became a ‘star’ overnight), playing the sleek but sick young gangster who enlists the help of a shabby, alcoholic doctor, the drunken angel of the title. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Drugstore cowboy
results.creator_credit: Avenue Pictures, Nick Wechsler, Karen Murphy and Gus Van Sant
results.brief_description: Gus Van Sant’s cynical but never moralistic story about a junkie couple whose domestic life centres on the pursuit of drugs. Matt Dillon and Kelly Lynch are outstanding as a couple of drifters who are not afraid to state their love for the pleasurable highs that drugs offer: compared to the existences of other people they meet in small-town America, they don’t think they are doing so badly. Alternating between the comic and the bleak, “Drugstore Cowboy” reveals the excess and pain of drug addiction but its sharp, cool and irreverent tone never condescends to, or patronises the viewer. Features an hilarious cameo by William Burroughs as a smacked-out priest.

results.title: Drop dead gorgeous
results.creator_credit: Capella, KC Medien, New Line Cinema, Gavin Polone, Judy Hofflund and Michael Patrick Jann
results.brief_description: Set in small town America, “Drop dead gorgeous” is a satire about teen beauty contests, ambitious parents and urban dysfunction. As the citizens of Mount Rose, Minnesota gear up for the Sarah Rose Miss Teen Princess America Pageant, the proceedings are filmed by a documentary crew, lending the film its mockumentary structure. The main contestants are Becky Leeman, whose ambitious mother runs the beauty contest and Amber Atkins, a plucky and talented working class teen who lives in a trailer park with her depressed alcoholic mother. When various contestants die in an array of mysterious circumstances Amber suspects that her life is in danger if she stays in competition. This film takes a savage view of American societal mores, as it mocks small town values, beauty contests, marriage, alcoholism, obesity, anorexia, paedophiles, handicapped people, mother-daughter relationships and the gauche self-consciousness of teenagers. It gladly follows in the footsteps of “Waiting for Guffman” and “Spinal tap”, but never reaches the hilarity of such predecessors, possibly due to its good natured and loveable heroine, contrasting too starkly with hideous caricatures. At times the black humour and merciless ridiculing of the screenplay are uncomfortable to watch, defiantly crossing over into bad taste on numerous occasions.

results.title: Driving Miss Daisy
results.creator_credit: Zanuck Company, Warner Bros Pictures, Richard Zanuck, Lili Zanuck and Bruce Beresford
results.brief_description: The funny, touching and totally irresistible story of a working relationship that became a twenty-five year friendship. When Daisy Werthan (Jessica Tandy) crashes her car, her son Boolie (Dan Ackroyd) insists that his mother’s driving days are over. He hires a chauffeur for her, Hoke Colburn (Morgan Freeman) to keep her out of trouble. But feisty Daisy resents the intrusion and she almost drives Hoke crazy with her insistence that she doesn’t need his help. Luckily, Hoke is a very patient man and the pair become the best of friends after 25 years of driving together. Winner of 4 Academy Awards including Best Picture and Best Actress. Screenplay by Alfred Uhry based on his play.

results.title: Driller killer [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Navaron Productions, D Metrov, Rochelle Weisberg and Abel Ferrara
results.brief_description: In retrospect, the notoriety surrounding Abel Ferrara’s early feature might have had more to do with the film’s provocative title than the content itself. At the time however, “Driller killer” became the scapegoat for the 80s ‘Video nasty’ hysteria, which saw the film unfairly lumped with other exploitation films such as “I spit on your grave” and “Blood sucking freaks.” Subsequently the film was either banned outright in some countries (including the UK), or severely modified for many years. Over the years however the film has enjoyed a renaissance of sorts mainly due to Ferrara’s growing reputation as a filmmaker. The grungy low budget look and punk sensibility of “Driller killer” is a perfect match for this story of a New York artist (played by Ferrara under the pseudonym Jimmy Laine) gradually driven insane. His only recourse from the insistent noise and chaos of the New York streets is to power tool anyone that gets in his way. Ferrara’s films, full of spiritual torment and redemption through bloodletting have seen the director compared to fellow New Yorker Martin Scorsese. With “Driller killer” however, its spiritual doppelganger ends up being Roman Polanski’s disturbing tale of madness, “Repulsion.” There’s even a perverse homage to the skinned rabbit from that film. Cast includes: Carolyn Marz, Baybi Day and Harry Schultz.

results.title: Drifting Clouds = Kauas pilvet karkaavat
results.brief_description: Lauri drives a tram and Ilona works as a hostess in a grand old hotel. Their life together in Helsinki seems peaceful until Lauri loses his job because the tram company is downsizing and Ilona is retrenched when the hotel she works for closes down. To make matters worse, Lauri has just purchased a brand new television on credit. Ilona takes a job in a greasy-spoon with questionable proprietors and Lauri, after selling the television and the car, indulges in a drinking binge which temporarily isolates him from his wife and home. Upon their reunion, life takes a positive turn when Ilona, with help from her old colleagues from the hotel, decides to open a restaurant, the Worker’s Rest cafe. “Drifting Clouds” is a quiet film enriched by the customary deadpan humour the Kaurismaki brothers are renowned for. Solemn, understated and rich with compassion, the characters are endearing for the genuine concern they show each other. Since the 1980’s the Kaurismaki brothers have produced their own style of absurdist comedy, tempered by a gentleness and minimalism which in “Drifting Clouds”, offsets the grim reality of themes like unemployment and poverty. Timo Salminen’s subtle photography and the strong use of primary colours in the set design create a film memorable for its fine detail and its pathos. Cast includes Kati Outinen and Kari Vaananen. In Finnish with English subtitles.

results.title: Dressed to kill
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures and Roy William Neill
results.brief_description: Adapted from a story by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and featuring the inimitable Sherlock Holmes (Basil Rathbone) and his sidekick, Dr Watson (Nigel Bruce). In this tale of mystery and suspense, Holmes has to find the whereabouts of three wooden music boxes containing Bank of England engraving plates in order to prevent certain crims out there from basically obtaining a licence to print money. Cast includes Patricia Morison, Edmond Breon, Frederick Worlock, Carl Harbord, Patricia Cameron.

results.title: Dragon lord = Long shaoye
results.creator_credit: Golden Harvest, Leonard Ho and Jackie Chan
results.brief_description: In this, the third in a trilogy of early films that Jackie Chan both directed and starred in, Chan refines his screen persona of the precocious, mischievious kung fu kid. Despite his comic buffoonery, when it comes to the crunch his highly honed martial arts skills save the day. Like the previous films in the trilogy (“The Fearless Hyena” (1979), “The Young Master” (1980)), ‘Dragon Lord’ is set in the countryside during the late Quing period. Chan plays the son of a wealthy man. He and his childhood friend spend their time participating in sporting events and competing to woo the village beauty. His carefree life takes a more serious turn when he stumbles upon a sinister villain who is attempting to smuggle priceless antiquities out of the country. The film features thrilling sporting sequences, a suspenseful rooftop encounter with a group of spear-wielding baddies, a playful acrobatic fight in an art gallery, and a show-stopping twenty minute final brawl that is a classic of Hong Kong action cinema. While not considered one of Chan’s best films, the over-the-top comic action sequences, featuring crazy stunts and rapid editing he pioneered in ‘Dragon Lord’ had a major impact on the subsequent development of Hong Kong action cinema. In Cantonese with English subtitles.

results.title: Dr. T & the women = Dr T and the women [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Sandcastle 5, James McLindon and Robert Altman
results.brief_description: ‘Dr.T & the women’ brings together an ensemble cast including Richard Gere, Helen Hunt, Farrah Fawcett and Kate Hudson. Gere plays Dr.T, a Dallas gynaecologist with a bevy of beautiful women who worship him. With his daughter’s wedding imminent, his wife’s lack of mental stability, his alcoholic sisters and her 3 children, it’s no wonder he finds solace in the arms of Bree, new pro teacher at the golf club.
